comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Eeek - it's not letting me scribble on the image! 

Sign in middle says MARYBOROUGH ROWING CLUB.  I reckon it is somewhere near Wharf Street due to the railway line which is still there, but the wooden wharfs are gone.  Possible a sugar mill in the background?

Looks like a happy occasion.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Hmmm - wondering if perhaps this has something to do with Anna Pavlova's tour of Queensland in 1929? I googled "sam hood maryborough photographer" and the first thing to pop up is this - dancelines.com.au/research/anna-pavlova/ . Trouble is, the article mentions Maryborough was cut out of the tour. ??? !!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hi beachcomber, long time no see! Hope you enjoyed your time away. 
That's strange about not being able to write a note. I checked the settings and it says that any Flickr member can write on it. Odd.
Thanks for spotting that! It is difficult to say whether or not this photograph is connected with Pavlova's tour. It certainly seems the right time, which I estimated based on the clothing! I suppose though, this would be difficult to confirm for certain. Fascinating information though, thanks.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] might have to forget that one...it wasn't all that helpful in dating this ANMM pic...

Looks like the vessel has been overrun by a crowd of bare-footed school children...I wonder what the chap dressed in all white has in his hand...it looks as if he's passing it to the woman seated in the chair...looks a bit like a clipboard...I wonder whether any movies were filmed at Maryborough in the 1920s?

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: My hunch is that the kids are from Maryborough Grammar School (which hit hard times during the Depression years and was taken over by the state education system in 1936)...whilst they're not exactly sporting Eton or Harrow outfits, they're still well dressed for kids living in the tropics... It's a pity the microfilm copy of the Maryborough Chronicle is such a dog (it's difficult to read...smudgy print...next to no photos)...which means that I won't be straining my eyes trawling thru it for clues. My theory is that this vessel might have been mentioned in the local news columns...particularly if it had been visited by a tribe of school children...almost front page news in a country town... Just going thru the digitised newspapers, it's apparent that by the later 1920s Sydney yachties were occasionally venturing up the Queensland coast on pleasure cruises...though this vessel looks to be a fairly substantial ketch or something similar...maybe some more clues will turn up at the ANMM down the track... www.tropikkal.com/francois/index.htm an interesting example of the kinds of pleasure cruises yachties were making along the Queensland coast in the 1920s...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Wow thanks for the image, great research! They all certainly are looking quite 'leisurely' :P What a lovely way to spend your spare time!
